newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU veterinary committee discusses swine fever.
newsitem.headline: EU veterinary committee discusses swine fever.

text.p: The European Union's Standing Veterinary Committee met on Wednesday in a special session called to discuss swine fever outbreaks in Germany and the Netherlands, a Commission official said.
"They are overviewing the situation and discussing possible new measures," a Commission official said.
On Tuesday, the EU formally imposed a partial ban on the export of pigs from five German Laender (states) and two districts in a sixth because of the outbreak.
German authorities have ordered the slaughter of up to 30,000 pigs to contain the highly contagious disease.

Dutch authorities, anxious to prevent restrictions of key pork exports, have decided to slaughter all pigs at 26 farms in the area immediately surrounding the first case discovered last Tuesday. An estimated 30,000 are expected to be killed.
The Netherlands exports around 750,000 tonnes of pigs and pork products every year.
On Friday, Poland closed its borders to all imports of Dutch pigs, pork and pork products and Belgium said it would tighten frontier checks, although it stopped short of an outright ban.
